FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE KINEMATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Chevron?s El Segundo Refinery began operations in 1911 making kerosene and other products.  Since that time, the products and processes have expanded to include the making of gasoline, jet, diesel and other petroleum based products.  Over the last 30 years, the government has undertaken more and more strenuous regulations of industrial air pollution and the prevention of major releases.  As part of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990(CAA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) was charged with overseeing the implementation of Section 112? of the Act.  

This section of the CAA requires industrial facilities that handle certain toxic substances or flammables to prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP) and implement an accidental release prevention program to prevent catastrophic releases of these substances into the environment and surrounding community.  The Act also provides for public communication of this RMP to establish dialog between facilities and the surrounding community concerning the risks associated the plant.

This document presents El Segundo Refinery?s RMP.  The refinery handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, aqueous ammonia and flammable substances in amounts over the EPA threshold limits for inclusion in an RMP.  The RMP lists these chemicals, the quantities handled, and describes various scenarios whereby such substances could be released into the community.  The facility?s release prevention programs are also discussed.  It should be noted that the refinery also handles other toxic substances that are not addressed in this document, even though the general refinery prevention programs do address them.  The refinery is available to discuss its hazardous substances or the contents of this document with community members at
(310) 615-5000 during business hours. During off-hours, emergency information requests or concerns should be directed to (310) 615-5342.

The Environmental Protection Agency has listed specific elements t

facility gate. 

1.2    The Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances Handled

Toxic Substances

This RMP includes two toxic substances: anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia.

Flammables

The refinery contains a large amount of flammable substances subject to the RMP. These range from the smallest compounds such as methane to larger ones such as pentane. Practically any process unit in the facility contains these substances in various mixtures. Since the process units and storage vessels vary in the composition of flammables present, each was looked at separately. 


1.3    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps
  
As discussed above, the refinery has been working with a PSM program under OSHA since the early 1990?s.  The EPA recognized this OSHA process in the development of the RMP program.  The OSHA program satisfies the RMP requirements for a prevention program.  The refinery?s PSM program elements include:

?    Process Safety Information
?    Process Hazards Analysis
?    Operating Procedures
?    Training
?    Mechanical Integrity
?    Management of Change
?    Pre-startup Safety Review
?    Compliance Audits
?    Incident Investigation
?    Employee Participation
?    Hot Work Permits
?    Contractors

The facility has fully implemented these elements under the OSHA standard. Additional prevention steps specific to ammonia include refinery specifications for new piping and equipment in ammonia service.  These specifications exceed most typical requirements for oil-handling equipment due to the unique hazards of ammonia.  The specifications include features such as having high reliability valves, minimal connections, using heat treated metals in vessels, selection of metals resistant to embrittlement during auto-refrigeration, and more isolation valves on liquid lines.
 

1.5    Five Year Accident History

There have been no incidents to report that fit the five-year criteria.


1.6    Emergency Response Program

The refinery maintains a full-time fire department with equipme

nt that meets the needs of responding to refinery fires and releases of chemicals.  An emergency response plan has been developed to address the following:

?    Specific actions to take in a response to an accidental release of hazardous chemicals;
?    Procedures for informing the public and the local agencies;
?    Information on emergency health care;
?    Information on how to communicate with the local emergency response agency;
?    Identification, maintenance, inspection and testing of emergency equipment; and
?    Training information.

This plan was developed in consultation with the local fire department.  The refinery fire fighters and emergency response personnel routinely drill and train to maintain their skills in emergency response.

 
1.7 Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

The El Segundo Refinery operated without an employee OSHA recordable injury between 5/14/03 and 8/13/04. This facility was recognized by the National Petroleum Refiners Association (NPRA) in 2003, 2004 and 2005 for its injury reduction.

Here are a few of the refinery's initiatives to improve employee and public safety:

The refinery continues to work with a consultant to improve alertness through focusing on biological factors that affect fatigue (lighting, shift cycles, etc.)

The refinery also continues to work with a consultant and internal committee to help further a refinery culture of safety through a program called "Incident and Injury Free." This program builds on fundamental safe work practices and the Refinery?s behavioral-based safety process and includes a strong element of contractor involvement.

The refinery has continued to upgrade its safety technology. An example is the use of disposable, clip-on LEL and H2S gas detectors. These detectors clip-on to clothing and alarm with detector limits are reached providing workers with continuous air monitoring.. Personnel can then don protective personal equipment or evacuate the work area.

All older eye wash/shower units are being replace

d and upgraded to the newer ANSI approved models. The Refinery Laboratory was first to get the new equipment, followed by process areas. This project costs over $800,000.

The refinery is implementing a new action tracking-based management of change (MOC) database. This database has been successfully employed at other industry locations. Once in place, not only will MOC?s be processed ?paperless,? but the process will be more efficient.

The Security Department continues to upgrade refinery security. In recent years, the refinery has upgraded its perimeter fencing, employee identification badge system and has undergone improvements to the main refinery contractor vehicle gate.

In 2006, the refinery will complete a seismic assessment utilizing the CalARP guidance document. The objective is to evaluate the need for retrofit structural strengthening to insure safety during an earthquake. Also in 2006, the Refinery is updating its facility siting data (API 752).
